Description: Indicates the type of the monitoring license offered to the eG manager.
Interpretation: This measure reports the license model used by the eG manager. Possible values and numeric codes are: Server Based=0, Server & Named Users Based=1, Server & Concurrent Users Based=2, No Expiry=9999. The textual value is shown in the measure, while graphs use the numeric equivalents.
troubleshootingSteps: Verify that the license type aligns with how you intend to use eG (server-only, named users, or concurrent users).
If planned usage changes (e.g., more digital workspace users), review whether the current license type remains appropriate.
Document license type and constraints so capacity and user growth are managed within the agreed model.
If you need to move from one license type to another, coordinate with eG Innovations to adjust contracts and keys.

Description: Indicates the total number of monitor licenses allocated to the eG manager.
Interpretation: This measure equals the sum of Premium monitors allowed and Basic monitors allowed and represents the overall monitoring capacity licensed for this manager.
troubleshootingSteps: Use this measure as the baseline capacity when planning how many components and tiers you can monitor.
Compare Total monitors allowed with current and projected monitoring needs to determine if additional licenses will be required.
When adding new components, ensure you remain within this total capacity and avoid unexpected license constraints.
If business plans require monitoring significantly more targets, initiate a license review with eG Innovations.

Description: Indicates the number of monitor licenses utilized currently by the eG manager.
Interpretation: A value close to Total monitors allowed indicates that licenses are depleting and additional licenses may be required to onboard more components.
troubleshootingSteps: Monitor this value as a percentage of Total monitors allowed to track how close you are to license saturation.
If utilization is consistently high, identify unused or decommissioned components that can be removed to free licenses.
Plan capacity upgrades in advance if growth trends show you will soon exceed current licensed monitors.
Use this measure in preventive maintenance reports to highlight license headroom risks to stakeholders.

Description: Indicates the number of monitor licenses that are available for use by the eG manager.
Interpretation: This measure represents remaining monitor capacity (Total monitors allowed minus Total monitors in use) and shows how many additional monitors can be configured. Generally customers will buy the license A free license lower than 50 licenses, is a cause of concern. eG Sales person to be informed about depleting licenses. Rapid consumption of licenses at short span of time is a cause of concern. A - value (hiphen) indicates that this license type is not applicable for this deployment and this can be treated as COMPLIANT or not-a-concern
troubleshootingSteps: Track this value over time to understand how quickly free monitoring capacity is being consumed.
Before onboarding new applications or environments, confirm that Total monitors available is sufficient.
If available monitors drop below an internal threshold (for example 10â€“20% of capacity), trigger a license review.
Where possible, reclaim monitors by removing obsolete components rather than immediately expanding licenses.

Description: Indicates the number of premium monitor licenses that were allocated to the eG manager.
Interpretation: This measure shows the licensed capacity for premium monitors, typically used for advanced or higher-value monitored components.
troubleshootingSteps: Review which components consume premium monitors and validate that they truly require premium-level monitoring.
Ensure premium monitor allocation matches business criticality (key services should be covered by premium monitors first).
If you consistently run out of premium capacity while basic capacity remains, consider rebalancing or increasing premium licenses.
Document which tiers use premium monitors so license audits and renewals are easier to manage.

Description: Indicates the number of premium monitor licenses utilized currently by the eG manager.
Interpretation: This shows current consumption of premium monitor capacity. High utilization relative to Premium monitors allowed indicates limited headroom for additional premium-monitored components.
troubleshootingSteps: Track premium utilization as a percentage of Premium monitors allowed to ensure sufficient headroom for planned additions.
Identify low-value or test components using premium monitors and consider downgrading them to basic where appropriate.
If critical projects require more premium monitoring than the current allocation, plan a license upgrade.
Include this metric in license utilization reports for stakeholders responsible for budgeting and renewals.

Description: Indicates the number of premium monitor licenses that are available for use by the eG manager.
Interpretation: This is the remaining premium monitoring capacity. A low value indicates that you are close to exhausting premium monitor licenses. A - value (hiphen) indicates that this license type is not applicable for this deployment and this can be treated as COMPLIANT or not-a-concern
troubleshootingSteps: Monitor this measure to ensure you have enough unused premium monitors for upcoming high-priority deployments.
Set internal thresholds to trigger alerts when Premium monitors available falls below a defined safety margin.
Review current premium assignments and reclaim licenses from non-critical or temporary components.
Discuss premium capacity planning with infrastructure and application owners so expansion is anticipated rather than reactive.

Description: Indicates the number of basic monitor licenses that were allocated to the eG manager.
Interpretation: This represents the licensed capacity for basic monitors, typically used for standard or less complex components.
troubleshootingSteps: Ensure that routine or less critical components are assigned basic rather than premium monitors where possible.
Compare Basic monitors allowed to the total number of lower-tier components to confirm adequate capacity.
If many basic monitors remain unused while premium capacity is tight, consider shifting suitable components from premium to basic.
Include this measure in license planning to balance basic vs premium allocations according to your environment mix.

Description: Indicates the number of basic monitor licenses utilized currently by the eG manager.
Interpretation: This shows current consumption of basic monitoring capacity. It helps you understand how widely basic monitoring is deployed across the environment.
troubleshootingSteps: Monitor trends in basic monitors usage as new infrastructure or services are onboarded.
If basic usage approaches Basic monitors allowed, review whether some components can be consolidated or removed.
Use this measure along with component inventory to verify that all required assets are being monitored.
If growth plans suggest significant expansion of monitored infrastructure, adjust basic license quantities accordingly.

Description: Indicates the number of basic monitor licenses that are available for use by the eG manager.
Interpretation: This is the remaining capacity for basic monitoring. A low value indicates that you are close to using all basic licenses. A - value (hiphen) indicates that this license type is not applicable for this deployment and this can be treated as COMPLIANT or not-a-concern
troubleshootingSteps: Track this measure to ensure adequate basic monitoring capacity for upcoming deployments or migrations.
If Basic monitors available becomes low, reclaim licenses by removing obsolete or duplicate monitored targets.
Set alert thresholds to notify administrators when basic capacity is nearly exhausted.
If future projects will add many standard components, plan a basic license expansion in advance.

Description: Indicates the number of users allowed to log in to the Thin client/VDI components managed and monitored by the eG manager.
Interpretation: This measure applies only to Server & Named Users Based and Server & Concurrent Users Based license types and reflects the total capacity of licensed digital workspace user/machine logins.
troubleshootingSteps: Compare allowed digital workspace licenses with the expected number of VDI/thin clients and users.
Ensure that your license allocation reflects peak concurrent usage patterns if you use concurrent licensing.
If planned VDI expansion will exceed current capacity, coordinate a license increase ahead of the rollout.
Document how these licenses are mapped to user groups or VDI pools for audit and planning purposes.

Measurement: Digital workspace user/machine licenses in use
Description: Indicates the number of users who are logged into the Thin client/VDI components monitored by the eG manager.
Interpretation: This measure, used with Digital workspace user/machine licenses allowed, shows current active consumption of digital workspace licenses under named or concurrent license models.
troubleshootingSteps: Monitor peak values to ensure active usage never exceeds licensed capacity in concurrent scenarios.
If usage frequently approaches or reaches the allowed limit, consider acquiring additional digital workspace licenses.
Analyze login patterns to see whether some sessions remain idle or unused and can be optimized.
Correlate high usage with end-user experience metrics to ensure capacity is adequate and users are not throttled.

Description: Indicates the number of users who can still log into the Thin client/VDI components monitored by the eG manager.
Interpretation: This applies to Server & Named Users Based and Server & Concurrent Users Based license types and indicates remaining capacity for digital workspace logins. A - value (hiphen) indicates that this license type is not applicable for this deployment and this can be treated as COMPLIANT or not-a-concern
troubleshootingSteps: Track remaining digital workspace licenses to ensure there is headroom for peak login periods (e.g., morning logon storms).
Set alert thresholds when available licenses fall below a defined buffer to avoid login denials.
Review inactive or orphaned accounts and sessions that might be consuming licenses unnecessarily.
Include this metric in digital workspace capacity planning discussions with EUC and VDI teams.

Description: Indicates the number of external agents that were configured to report to the eG manager.
Interpretation: This measure shows how many external agents are deployed and connected to this manager, reflecting the scale of distributed monitoring.
troubleshootingSteps: Compare the count of external agents with your architecture design to ensure all required locations and zones are covered.
Investigate discrepancies where expected agents are not counted, which may indicate connectivity or registration issues.
Periodically review and remove agents that are no longer needed to simplify management and reduce overhead.
Correlate external agent counts with agent health metrics to ensure all agents are functioning as expected.

Description: Indicates the number of unique IP addresses that can be monitored by the eG manager.
Interpretation: This measure reflects the number of distinct target entities (by IP) under monitoring. It is useful for understanding environment coverage relative to licensing and design.
troubleshootingSteps: Compare Monitored targets with your CMDB or asset inventory to identify gaps in monitoring coverage.
If the number of monitored targets is close to or exceeds expectations, verify that no duplicate or obsolete entries exist.
Use this measure alongside license utilization metrics to ensure sufficient capacity for all required targets.
Plan expansions in Monitored targets in line with infrastructure growth and license limits.

Description: Indicates the number of applications that can be monitored by the eG manager.
Interpretation: This measure shows the count of application entities configured for monitoring and helps assess the breadth of application-level coverage.
troubleshootingSteps: Validate that all critical business applications are included in this count and are configured for monitoring.
Review application inventory regularly to ensure new applications are added and retired ones are removed.
If the number of monitored applications is lower than expected, identify missing apps and add appropriate monitors.
If approaching any application-related license or design limits, plan for license or architecture adjustments.

Description: Indicates the number of network devices that can be monitored by the eG manager.
Interpretation: This measure reflects how many network devices (such as switches, routers, firewalls) are configured for monitoring.
troubleshootingSteps: Compare this count with your network inventory to confirm that key devices are being monitored.
Identify any network segments with insufficient monitoring coverage and onboard additional devices as needed.
Remove monitoring for decommissioned or unused devices to keep configuration clean and conserve licenses.
Use this metric to plan growth in network monitoring as the infrastructure expands.

Description: Indicates the total number of topology segments that can be configured on the eG manager.
Interpretation: This measure shows how many logical topology segments are defined or allowed, which helps organize monitored components by function, location, or service.
troubleshootingSteps: Review the number and structure of segments to ensure they reflect current topology and service organization.
If segments are underutilized, consider using them to improve visualization, reporting, and ownership mapping.
Avoid excessive fragmentation into many tiny segments that may complicate management.
Align segments with organizational boundaries (e.g., business units, data centers) for clearer accountability.

Description: Indicates the total number of services that can be configured and monitored as logical groups within the eG manager.
Interpretation: This measure reflects how many end-to-end or composite services are modeled for monitoring, which helps align technical metrics with business services.
troubleshootingSteps: Ensure that key business services (e.g., ERP, email, VDI service) are defined as services in eG and counted by this metric.
If services are not modeled, consider creating them to provide clearer end-to-end visibility and reporting.
Periodically review service definitions to retire obsolete ones and adjust components included in each service.
Use service-level modeling to drive SLA/SLO reporting and preventive maintenance discussions with stakeholders.

Description: Indicates the number of users permitted to access the eG monitoring console of the eG manager.
Interpretation: This measure represents the licensed or configured capacity for monitoring console users and reflects how many individuals can directly use the eG UI.
troubleshootingSteps: Compare Monitor users with Non-default users and actual usage metrics to understand adoption levels.
If many monitor user slots are unused, consider onboarding additional team members who would benefit from direct access.
If you hit the limit of monitor users, review inactive accounts and remove or disable them to free capacity.
Align the number of monitor users with support model changes (e.g., onboarding new NOC teams or MSP partners).

Description: Indicates the number of days beyond which the license to the eG manager will expire.
Interpretation: This measure shows the remaining validity period of the eG manager license. A low value indicates that renewal or extension is required soon to avoid disruption.
troubleshootingSteps: Monitor this measure regularly and define internal thresholds (e.g., 90, 60, 30 days) to trigger renewal planning.
Share upcoming expiry information with procurement, vendor management, and technical owners to align budgeting and approvals.
Ensure that any changes in environment scope (more monitors, users, or features) are considered during renewal negotiations.
Avoid last-minute renewals that risk license lapse and potential monitoring outages.
